<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Flag indicating whether the register is actually restored in the epilog.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// In most cases, if a register is saved, it is also restored. There are</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// some situations, though, when this is not the case. For example, the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// LR register on ARM is usually saved, but on exit from the function its</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// saved value may be loaded directly into PC. Since liveness tracking of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// physical registers treats callee-saved registers are live outside of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// the function, LR would be treated as live-on-exit, even though in these</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// scenarios it is not. This flag is added to indicate that the saved</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// register described by this object is not restored in the epilog.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// The long-term solution is to model the liveness of callee-saved registers</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// by implicit uses on the return instructions, however, the required</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// changes in the ARM backend would be quite extensive.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The MachineFrameInfo class represents an abstract stack frame until</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// prolog/epilog code is inserted.  This class is key to allowing stack frame</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// representation optimizations, such as frame pointer elimination.  It also</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// allows more mundane (but still important) optimizations, such as reordering</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// of abstract objects on the stack frame.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="83"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// To support this, the class assigns unique integer identifiers to stack</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00084" /><CodeLine lineNumber="84"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// objects requested clients.  These identifiers are negative integers for</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00085" /><CodeLine lineNumber="85"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// fixed stack objects (such as arguments passed on the stack) or nonnegative</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00086" /><CodeLine lineNumber="86"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// for objects that may be reordered.  Instructions which refer to stack</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="87"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// objects use a special MO&#95;FrameIndex operand to represent these frame</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="88"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// indexes.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="89"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="90"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Because this class keeps track of all references to the stack frame, it</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="91"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// knows when a variable sized object is allocated on the stack.  This is the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="92"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// sole condition which prevents frame pointer elimination, which is an</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="93"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// important optimization on register-poor architectures.  Because original</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="94"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// variable sized alloca&#39;s in the source program are the only source of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="95"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// variable sized stack objects, it is safe to decide whether there will be</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="96"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// any variable sized objects before all stack objects are known (for</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="97"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// example, register allocator spill code never needs variable sized</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="98"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// objects).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="99"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="100"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// When prolog/epilog code emission is performed, the final stack frame is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="101"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// built and the machine instructions are modified to refer to the actual</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="102"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// stack offsets of the object, eliminating all MO&#95;FrameIndex operands from</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="103"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// the program.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="104"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="105"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Abstract Stack Frame Information</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="106" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo"><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">class </span><span class="doxyHighlight"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a22785bee142f66d053d8a7742d12820f">MachineFrameInfo</a> &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="107"><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">public</span><span class="doxyHighlight">:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="108"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Stack Smashing Protection (SSP) rules require that vulnerable stack</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="109"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// allocations are located close the stack protector.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="110" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a3df888d2d0447ad8ff7b616b080d9f13"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">enum</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a3df888d2d0447ad8ff7b616b080d9f13">SSPLayoutKind</a> &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a3df888d2d0447ad8ff7b616b080d9f13ae58c4225f24cd64ac3846a49952e48e1"><span class="doxyHighlight">    <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a3df888d2d0447ad8ff7b616b080d9f13ae58c4225f24cd64ac3846a49952e48e1">SSPLK&#95;None</a>,       </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///&lt; Did not trigger a stack protector.  No effect on data</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Represent a single object allocated on the stack.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">struct </span><span class="doxyHighlight">StackObject &#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The offset of this object from the stack pointer on entry to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the function.  This field has no meaning for a variable sized element.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><span class="doxyHighlight">    int64&#95;t SPOffset;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The size of this object on the stack. 0 means a variable sized object,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// ~0ULL means a dead object.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><span class="doxyHighlight">    uint64&#95;t <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/inlineorder-cpp/#a7ee6f0cb51c3b9056199e9a0001fe8c3a6f6cb72d544962fa333e2e34ce64f719">Size</a>;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The required alignment of this stack slot.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133"><span class="doxyHighlight">    <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/align">Align</a> Alignment;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="135"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If true, the value of the stack object is set before</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00136" /><CodeLine lineNumber="136"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// entering the function and is not modified inside the function. By</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00137" /><CodeLine lineNumber="137"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// default, fixed objects are immutable unless marked otherwise.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> isImmutable;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If true the stack object is used as spill slot. It</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// cannot alias any other memory objects.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> isSpillSlot;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// If true, this stack slot is used to spill a value (could be deopt</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00145" /><CodeLine lineNumber="145"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// and/or GC related) over a statepoint. We know that the address of the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00146" /><CodeLine lineNumber="146"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// slot can&#39;t alias any LLVM IR value.  This is very similar to a Spill</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00147" /><CodeLine lineNumber="147"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// Slot, but is created by statepoint lowering is SelectionDAG, not the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00148" /><CodeLine lineNumber="148"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// register allocator.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00149" /><CodeLine lineNumber="149"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> isStatepointSpillSlot = </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">false</span><span class="doxyHighlight">;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00150" /><CodeLine lineNumber="150"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00151" /><CodeLine lineNumber="151"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// Identifier for stack memory type analagous to address space. If this is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00152" /><CodeLine lineNumber="152"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// non-0, the meaning is target defined. Offsets cannot be directly</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00153" /><CodeLine lineNumber="153"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// compared between objects with different stack IDs. The object may not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00154" /><CodeLine lineNumber="154"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// necessarily reside in the same contiguous memory block as other stack</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00155" /><CodeLine lineNumber="155"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// objects. Objects with differing stack IDs should not be merged or</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00156" /><CodeLine lineNumber="156"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// replaced substituted for each other.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00157" /><CodeLine lineNumber="157"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00158" /><CodeLine lineNumber="158"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// It is assumed a target uses consecutive, increasing stack IDs starting</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00159" /><CodeLine lineNumber="159"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// from 1</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00160" /><CodeLine lineNumber="160"><span class="doxyHighlight">    uint8&#95;t StackID;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00161" /><CodeLine lineNumber="161"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00162" /><CodeLine lineNumber="162"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// If this stack object is originated from an Alloca instruction</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00163" /><CodeLine lineNumber="163"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// this value saves the original IR allocation. Can be NULL.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00164" /><CodeLine lineNumber="164"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/allocainst">AllocaInst</a> &#42;Alloca;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00165" /><CodeLine lineNumber="165"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00166" /><CodeLine lineNumber="166"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If true, the object was mapped into the local frame</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00167" /><CodeLine lineNumber="167"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// block and doesn&#39;t need additional handling for allocation beyond that.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00168" /><CodeLine lineNumber="168"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> PreAllocated = </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">false</span><span class="doxyHighlight">;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00169" /><CodeLine lineNumber="169"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00170" /><CodeLine lineNumber="170"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If true, an LLVM IR value might point to this object.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00171" /><CodeLine lineNumber="171"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Normally, spill slots and fixed-offset objects don&#39;t alias IR-accessible</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00172" /><CodeLine lineNumber="172"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// objects, but there are exceptions (on PowerPC, for example, some byval</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00173" /><CodeLine lineNumber="173"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// arguments have ABI-prescribed offsets).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00174" /><CodeLine lineNumber="174"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> isAliased;</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00176" /><CodeLine lineNumber="176"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">    /// If true, the object has been zero-extended.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00180" /><CodeLine lineNumber="180"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> isSExt = </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">false</span><span class="doxyHighlight">;</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00194" /><CodeLine lineNumber="194"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00195" /><CodeLine lineNumber="195"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Can the stack be realigned. This can be false if the target does not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00196" /><CodeLine lineNumber="196"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// support stack realignment, or if the user asks us not to realign the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00197" /><CodeLine lineNumber="197"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// stack. In this situation, overaligned allocas are all treated as dynamic</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00198" /><CodeLine lineNumber="198"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// allocations and the target must handle them as part of DYNAMIC&#95;STACKALLOC</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00199" /><CodeLine lineNumber="199"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// lowering. All non-alloca stack objects have their alignment clamped to the</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00201" /><CodeLine lineNumber="201"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// FIXME: There is room for improvement in this case, in terms of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00202" /><CodeLine lineNumber="202"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// grouping overaligned allocas into a &quot;secondary stack frame&quot; and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00203" /><CodeLine lineNumber="203"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// then only use a single alloca to allocate this frame and only a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00204" /><CodeLine lineNumber="204"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// single virtual register to access it. Currently, without such an</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00239" /><CodeLine lineNumber="239"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// The prolog/epilog code inserter calculates the final stack</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00240" /><CodeLine lineNumber="240"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// offsets for all of the fixed size objects, updating the Objects list</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00241" /><CodeLine lineNumber="241"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// above.  It then updates StackSize to contain the number of bytes that need</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00242" /><CodeLine lineNumber="242"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// to be allocated on entry to the function.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00243" /><CodeLine lineNumber="243"><span class="doxyHighlight">  uint64&#95;t StackSize = 0;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00244" /><CodeLine lineNumber="244"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00245" /><CodeLine lineNumber="245"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// The amount that a frame offset needs to be adjusted to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00246" /><CodeLine lineNumber="246"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// have the actual offset from the stack/frame pointer.  The exact usage of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00247" /><CodeLine lineNumber="247"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// this is target-dependent, but it is typically used to adjust between</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00248" /><CodeLine lineNumber="248"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// SP-relative and FP-relative offsets.  E.G., if objects are accessed via</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00249" /><CodeLine lineNumber="249"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// SP then OffsetAdjustment is zero; if FP is used, OffsetAdjustment is set</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00250" /><CodeLine lineNumber="250"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// to the distance between the initial SP and the value in FP.  For many</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00251" /><CodeLine lineNumber="251"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// targets, this value is only used when generating debug info (via</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00252" /><CodeLine lineNumber="252"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// TargetRegisterInfo::getFrameIndexReference); when generating code, the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00253" /><CodeLine lineNumber="253"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// corresponding adjustments are performed directly.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00254" /><CodeLine lineNumber="254"><span class="doxyHighlight">  int64&#95;t OffsetAdjustment = 0;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00255" /><CodeLine lineNumber="255"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00256" /><CodeLine lineNumber="256"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// The prolog/epilog code inserter may process objects that require greater</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00257" /><CodeLine lineNumber="257"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// alignment than the default alignment the target provides.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00258" /><CodeLine lineNumber="258"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// To handle this, MaxAlignment is set to the maximum alignment</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00259" /><CodeLine lineNumber="259"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// needed by the objects on the current frame.  If this is greater than the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00260" /><CodeLine lineNumber="260"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// native alignment maintained by the compiler, dynamic alignment code will</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00261" /><CodeLine lineNumber="261"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// be needed.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00262" /><CodeLine lineNumber="262"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  ///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00263" /><CodeLine lineNumber="263"><span class="doxyHighlight">  <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/amdgpu/hsamd/kernel/arg/key/#a6b334a5f83504ebc99cc59f4f333ff98">Align</a> MaxAlignment;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00264" /><CodeLine lineNumber="264"></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00389" /><CodeLine lineNumber="389"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// selection is complete to determine if there is a call to builtin</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00390" /><CodeLine lineNumber="390"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// \\@llvm.experimental.patchpoint.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00393" /><CodeLine lineNumber="393"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00394" /><CodeLine lineNumber="394"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Return true if this function requires a split stack prolog, even if it</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00395" /><CodeLine lineNumber="395"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// uses no stack space. This is only meaningful for functions where</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00396" /><CodeLine lineNumber="396"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// MachineFunction::shouldSplitStack() returns true.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00397" /><CodeLine lineNumber="397"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00398" /><CodeLine lineNumber="398"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For non-leaf functions we have to allow for the possibility that the call</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00399" /><CodeLine lineNumber="399"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// is to a non-split function, as in PR37807. This function could also take</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00400" /><CodeLine lineNumber="400"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the address of a non-split function. When the linker tries to adjust its</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00401" /><CodeLine lineNumber="401"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// non-existent prologue, it would fail with an error. Mark the object file so</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00402" /><CodeLine lineNumber="402"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that such failures are not errors. See this Go language bug-report</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00403" /><CodeLine lineNumber="403"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// https://go-review.googlesource.com/c/go/+/148819/</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00404" /><CodeLine lineNumber="404" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a00d2c6aab11836fcd2116ef07924253e"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a00d2c6aab11836fcd2116ef07924253e">needsSplitStackProlog</a>()</span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword"> const </span><span class="doxyHighlight">&#123;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00405" /><CodeLine lineNumber="405"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordFlow">return</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a14c39a24bf6ebbe339ae8a453c7fdd11">getStackSize</a>() != 0 || <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineframeinfo/#a763b7a1e7127b495f396b30f0d9c95f1">hasTailCall</a>();</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00687" /><CodeLine lineNumber="687"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Create a new object at a fixed location on the stack.</span></CodeLine>
